title: PSA: Infernal Drake isn't nearly as good as you probably think it is
body:
I keep hearing people say that it gives 8% more damage against champions. It actually increases your AD and AP ratios by 8% when calculating damage against champions. This means it does nothing for your clearing or objective taking, and that champions with lower ratios and core items with less raw AP/AD receive less benefit from it. Supports and full tanks in particular gain almost nothing from Infernal Drake. It's even _worse_ when you're dealing with a spell that uses bonus AD scaling instead of total AD. Here's a little something I just posted on Reddit:

>A Zed with Ghostblade and Cleaver deals 309 damage with Q at max rank. Infernal drake bumps that up to 316.92. This means Infernal Drake effectively added 7.92 damage to Zed's Q. If it did a flat 8% more damage, he would've gained 24.72 damage, well over triple that.

I'm definitely not saying that Infernal drake is bad, more damage can always be appreciated, and the global exp is nothing to scoff at. I just wanted to let people know this.

What this means is that Infernal Drake makes you stronger VS Baron, Dragon, Minions, Champions and Towers. You're underestimating the buff heavily based off of misinformation.

> This can be more than 8% damage, if you're an AA heavy champ who buys a lot of crit your damage will increase by more than 8%,

Actually, that is a bit inaccurate. You can never get above an 8% damage boost from the dragon by being an autoattacker, because no matter how much crit and attack speed you have, your autoattack damage will always increase by exactly 8% with each dragon buff (unless you have some form of ability damage on your autos like Vayne). I can prove this with an example.

Say we have 100 AD, 1 attack per second and 50% crit chance (this numbers are obviously fake, but they're just for simplicity's sake). Over 4 attacks, you would expect to do 600 damage (2 hits for 100, 2 crits for 200). 8% of 600 is 48. If you had 8 bonus AD from the dragon, you would expect to do 648 damage (2 hits for 108, 2 crits for 216). So, you have an increase in autoattack damage of exactly 8%. You can do this with any values for AD, crit and attack speed, and I promise you that the increase to autoattack dps from a dragon will always equal 8%, unless you have an on-hit effect like Varus W (the dragon will not increase the base damage of the on-hit, so Varus will get less than an 8% increase).

So, basically, the more damage you get from autoattacks and from bonus AD/AP scaling, and the less you get from ability base damage, the closer to an 8% damage boost you will get from a dragon. That's actually a good way to determine exactly how ham you should go for the infernal drake, and exactly how many of your team it is worth abandoning to guarantee that nice juicy fire dragon damage.

Well, Varus's W scales with AP, so if you had some AP before, you will get a bit more AP, technically increasing the damage by 8%.

Still agree with everything else.

>technically increasing the damage by 8%.

It won't be an increase of 8% to his autoattack damage, because it won't boost the base damage of the W. The W's AP ratio damage will be boosted by 8%, but the base will be unaltered. This guarantees that the skill's damage will be increased by some value that will always be less than 8%. I can work out an equation to prove this if you like.

No ability that has a base damage will have its damage increased by 8%. The only reason autoattacks get an 8% increase is because there technically is no base damage. All of the AD used for autoattacks gets increased, while for skills, the base damage is unaltered but the ratio damage is increased by 8%.

5 champions x 100% damage per champion = 500% damage.

Person B does 108

I'm saying that the Infernal Drake isn't so strong as an early game buff, but as the game goes on, it becomes more valuable.  It's the same reason mages don't build a Rabadon's as their first item, % increases aren't that great early on.  It's only once you have a few items that it becomes strong.

Really, Mountain Drake is great in general.  It makes it easy to build a non-champion based lead, which is most of what is done in pro games.

> and that champions with lower ratios and core items with less raw AP/AD receive less benefit from it. 

Ratios are usually pretty proportional to base damage.

With 8% more AP/AD though: the base QWER of most champions reaches ~1000 when they reach level 18, with a 220% AP ratio (or requiring 450 AP) to deal 2000 damage.

As such: champions with 450 AP would only receive 4% more damage from 8% more AP. Or if you figure 150/300/450 damage at rank 1,2,and 3 R over the course of a game: with 150 AP @6, 300 @11, and 450 @16 you'd only do 4% more damage.
And to get that level of AP at those points in the game you have to go glass-cannon AP, often sacrificing mana and mana regeneration to get there. 
Same general thing applies on the AD side.

--------------

So yeah: what looks like 8% is 4% best-case scenario in most cases, more realistically less. And less then 1% for most supports, tanks, and juggernauts.
